questions.text: Identify the condition associated with the murmur depicted in the image below.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A pansystolic murmur best heard at the apex and radiating to the axilla is characteristic of mitral regurgitation.

  • The image provided shows a pansystolic murmur, also known as a holosystolic murmur, which is a hallmark of mitral regurgitation (MR).
  • MR occurs when the mitral valve fails to close properly during systole, leading to retrograde flow of blood from the left ventricle (LV) to the left atrium (LA).
  • This murmur:
    • Begins with S1 and continues through to S2, hence the term pansystolic.
    • Is best heard at the apex of the heart.
    • Characteristically radiates to the axilla.
    • May be associated with a soft or absent S1, especially in chronic MR where the mitral valve leaflets are already poorly mobile.
    • Clinical signs of MR include:
      • Dyspnea (due to pulmonary congestion)
      • Fatigue (from reduced cardiac output)
      • Orthopnea, and
      • Atrial fibrillation (due to left atrial dilation)

questions.text: A young man came to the medical OPD with complaints of early morning backache and stiffness, which improves on exercise, and persistent red eyes. On examination, lung expansion was less than 3 cm. X-ray is shown in the image given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The classic triad of inflammatory back pain, reduced chest expansion, and uveitis strongly suggests ankylosing spondylitis, supported by the “bamboo spine” seen on X-ray. 

  • Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS) is a chronic inflammatory seronegative spondyloarthropathy that primarily affects the spine and sacroiliac joints.
  • The hallmark feature is inflammatory back pain, which is worse in the morning or after periods of inactivity, and improves with exercise.
  • Reduced lung expansion (<3 cm) is due to costovertebral joint involvement.
  • The patient also has persistent red eyes, suggesting anterior uveitis, the most common extra-articular manifestation of AS.
  • Characteristic radiological features of AS seen in this case:
    • Sacroiliitis: bilateral and symmetrical involvement with erosion, sclerosis, and eventual fusion.
    • Syndesmophyte formation leads to bamboo spine appearance on X-ray.
    • Dagger sign: a radiodense line due to ossification of interspinous and supraspinous ligaments.
  • Other clinical features include:
    • Enthesitis (especially at Achilles tendon, plantar fascia)
    • Peripheral large joint arthritis (hip, shoulder)
    • Postural changes: forward stooping due to thoracic kyphosis
    • Fatigue, anemia of chronic disease, and rarely cardiac/aortic involvement
  • Investigations:
    • HLA-B27 positive in >90% of patients
    • Elevated ESR, CRP
    • MRI is more sensitive than X-ray in early disease

Explanation of other options:

Paget's Disease (Option B): Characterized by abnormal bone remodeling with cortical thickening and lytic-sclerotic lesions, not vertebral fusion or syndesmophytes. Does not cause morning stiffness or uveitis.

Healed Tuberculosis (Option C): Pott's spine may cause vertebral collapse or gibbus deformity, but not the bamboo spine appearance. Uveitis and reduced lung expansion are uncommon.

Osteopetrosis (Option D): A genetic disorder with diffuse bone sclerosis due to defective osteoclast function. X-rays show dense bones, but there is no inflammatory back pain, uveitis, or vertebral fusion.

questions.text: A patient with hyperkalemia and elevated urea levels underwent dialysis. Towards the end of the session, she became drowsy and had a sudden seizure episode. On examination, the patient was hypotensive. What is the treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient is experiencing dialysis disequilibrium syndrome (DDS), managed with IV Mannitol to reduce cerebral oedema.

  • Dialysis Disequilibrium Syndrome (DDS) is an acute neurological complication typically seen during or after the first hemodialysis session, particularly in patients with severe azotemia.
  • It is caused by the rapid removal of urea from the blood, creating a reverse urea gradient between the plasma and cerebrospinal fluid.
  • This leads to osmotic movement of water into the brain, resulting in cerebral edema.
  • Clinical features include headache, nausea, vomiting, blurred vision, restlessness, confusion, tremors, muscle cramps, and in severe cases, seizures or coma.
  • Risk factors include very high BUN levels (>175 mg/dL), first dialysis session, rapid dialysis, pediatric or elderly patients, and underlying neurological disorders.
  • Management includes:
    • Administering IV Mannitol to reduce cerebral edema.
    • Modifying dialysis parameters to slow solute removal.
    • Supportive care.
  • Prevention includes:
    • Initiating dialysis slowly with shorter sessions.
    • Adjusting dialysate composition (e.g., higher sodium).
    • Avoiding rapid correction of severe uremia.

Explanation of other options:

Bumetanide (Option A): A loop diuretic used for fluid overload; does not address the osmotic cerebral oedema in DDS.

Ethacrynic acid (Option B): Another loop diuretic; not effective in treating the cerebral osmotic shifts seen in DDS.

Nesiritide (Option C): A B-type natriuretic peptide analogue used in acute heart failure, not indicated for DDS.

Reference:

NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: A female patient presents with severe restlessness, palpitations, and tremors to the emergency department. She is a known case of bronchial asthma. On examination, the neck looks swollen. Blood pressure is elevated, and tachycardia is noted. ECG shows atrial fibrillation. Which of the following drugs is used for immediate management in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Diltiazem is preferred for rate control in atrial fibrillation in thyroid storm when beta-blockers are contraindicated, such as in bronchial asthma.

  • The patient's presentation-restlessness, palpitations, tremors, tachycardia, atrial fibrillation, and a swollen neck-suggests thyroid storm, a life-threatening complication of hyperthyroidism.
    • Clinical features:
    • Fever
    • Delirium, seizures, coma
    • Vomiting, diarrhea
    • Jaundice
    • Hyperthermia
    • Cardiac failure
    • Arrhythmias
  • Precipitating factors:
    • Stress:
      • Acute illnesses like stroke, trauma, diabetic ketoacidosis
      • Surgery, commonly of the thyroid
      • Infections
    • Acute iodine load:
      • Radioiodine treatment of a patient with partially or untreated hyperthyroidism
      • Iodinated contrast agents
      • Amiodarone administration
  • In thyroid storm, immediate management involves controlling the heart rate, especially in cases of atrial fibrillation.
  • Beta-blockers like propranolol and esmolol are commonly used to manage symptoms and block peripheral conversion of T4 to T3.
  • However, they are contraindicated in bronchial asthma due to their bronchoconstrictive potential.
  • In asthmatic patients, diltiazem, a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker, is used instead for rate control as it avoids bronchospasm.
  • After initial stabilization and rate control, antithyroid drugs like propylthiouracil are administered to block thyroid hormone synthesis.

Explanation of other options:

Propranolol (Option B): Beta-blocker used in thyroid storm, but contraindicated in asthma due to risk of bronchospasm.

Esmolol (Option C): Short-acting beta-blocker also used in thyroid storm; however, not preferred in asthmatics.

Propylthiouracil (Option D): Drug of choice to inhibit thyroid hormone synthesis in thyroid storm, but not used first in unstable patients with atrial fibrillation-rate control is the immediate priority.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1681414/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK448095/

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is found to be positive for HBsAg and HBeAg and is diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B. The viral load of the patient was 2 x 100,000, and SGPT is found to be doubled. What is the appropriate management in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tenofovir is a first-line potent antiviral agent for chronic hepatitis B with high efficacy and low resistance, recommended for long-term therapy.

  • The patient meets the criteria for chronic hepatitis B infection, confirmed by persistent HBsAg and HBeAg positivity, elevated viral load (2 × 100,000), and raised SGPT indicating active liver inflammation.
  • The goal in managing chronic HBV is to suppress viral replication, reduce hepatic inflammation, and prevent progression to cirrhosis or hepatocellular carcinoma.
  • Tenofovir is a nucleotide analog and one of the first-line oral agents for treating chronic HBV.
  • It has high potency, a favorable resistance profile, and effectively reduces HBV DNA, normalizes ALT, and improves liver histology.
  • It is administered once daily and typically continued for more than 40 weeks (usually 48-52 weeks or longer depending on clinical response).
  • Tenofovir also has a better side effect profile compared to older drugs, although monitoring for renal dysfunction and hypophosphatemia is advised.
  • Key drugs used in chronic Hepatitis B treatment include:
    • Interferons: Peginterferon alfa-2a, interferon alfa-2b
    • Nucleoside analogs: Entecavir, lamivudine, telbivudine
    • Nucleotide analogs: Adefovir, tenofovir
    • First-line oral agents:
      • Entecavir, Tenofovir
    • Second-line agents (less preferred due to resistance):
      • Lamivudine, adefovir, telbivudine
  • Duration of therapy is generally 48-52 weeks, with long-term therapy depending on viral suppression and liver response.
  • Lifestyle modification is also critical: avoid alcohol, hepatotoxic drugs, and unregulated herbal medications.

Explanation of other options:

Lamivudine for 30+ weeks (Option A): Lamivudine is an older nucleoside analog that suppresses HBV replication but has a high risk of resistance and is considered a second-line agent. Hence, not preferred over tenofovir.

Pegylated interferon for 52 weeks (Option C): Although pegylated interferon is used for finite-duration treatment, it is less tolerated, requires subcutaneous administration, and is less effective than oral agents like tenofovir in most patients.

Combined pegylated interferon with lamivudine (Option D): Combination therapy does not offer significant advantage over monotherapy and increases the risk of side effects, making it less preferred in standard management protocols.

Reference:

Hepatitis B - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient came with complaints of palpitations, sweating, and restlessness. He has a complaint of sweaty palms. Clinical findings are depicted in the image given below. What is the diagnostic finding seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Thyroid receptor antibodies (TRAb), especially thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI), are diagnostic of Graves' disease, which this patient exhibits.

  • The patient's symptoms-palpitations, sweating, restlessness, and sweaty palms-are classic for hyperthyroidism.
  • The most likely diagnosis is Graves' disease, an autoimmune disorder in which thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI) bind to and activate TSH receptors on the thyroid gland.
  • This leads to increased production of T3 and T4, causing hyperthyroid symptoms.
  • In Graves' ophthalmopathy, characteristic signs include:
    • Dalrymple's sign: Upper lid retraction due to Muller's muscle contraction (most common presenting sign)
    • Von Graefe's sign: Lid lag on downward gaze and stare due to poor blinking, often earliest sign
    • Enroth's sign: Lower eyelid fullness/edema
    • Mobius sign: Weak convergence
    • Griffith's sign: Lower lid lag on upward gaze
    • Stellwag's sign: Infrequent/incomplete blinking
    • Joffroy's sign: Absent forehead wrinkling on upward gaze
    • Gellineck's sign: Hyperpigmentation of the eyelids
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by:
    • Elevated TSI or TRAb levels
    • Thyroid function tests showing elevated T3/T4 and suppressed TSH
    • Radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU): Increased in Graves'
  • Management includes:
    • Antithyroid drugs (Methimazole or PTU)
    • Radioactive iodine ablation
    • Surgery for large goiters or resistant cases
    • Graves' ophthalmopathy: Corticosteroids, radiotherapy, or orbital decompression in severe cases

Explanation of other options:

Anti-thyroglobulin antibody (Option A): Commonly elevated in autoimmune hypothyroidism like Hashimoto's, not specific for Graves'.

Anti-thyroid peroxidase antibody (Option B): Typically seen in Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

Elevated ultrasensitive thyrotropin (TSH) levels (Option D): TSH is suppressed in hyperthyroid states like Graves'- disease due to negative feedback.

Reference:
Pubmed

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK582134/table/article-142674.table0/

https://eyewiki.org/Thyroid_Eye_Disease#:~:text=Eyelid%20retraction%20(Dalrymple's%20sign)%20is,bilateral%20axial%20proptosis%20(exophthalmos)

questions.text: A 50-year-old HIV patient presented with a painful lesion, as shown ?in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Kaposi sarcoma presents as violaceous lesions on the skin or mucosa, commonly seen in HIV-positive individuals due to HHV-8 infection.

  • The lesion shown in the image is a violaceous plaque located on the hard palate in an HIV-positive patient, which is highly suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma (KS).
  • KS is a vascular tumor associated with human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) and is classified as an AIDS-defining illness.
  • It typically involves the skin, oral mucosa, and internal organs like the lungs and GI tract.
  • Clinical stages:
    • Patch stage: Flat, pink or red macules.
    • Plaque stage: Raised purple or brown lesions.
    • Nodular stage: Firm, raised nodules that may ulcerate.
  • Variants of KS:
    • Classic KS: Older Mediterranean or Eastern European males.
    • Endemic KS: Seen in younger individuals in sub-Saharan Africa.
    • Transplant-associated KS: Occurs in patients on immunosuppressants.
    • AIDS-associated KS: Occurs in HIV/AIDS, especially with low CD4 counts.
  • Pathophysiology: HHV-8 infects endothelial cells, promoting angiogenesis and spindle cell proliferation.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Biopsy showing spindle cells, angiogenesis, and extravasated RBCs.
    • PCR or serology for HHV-8 may support the diagnosis.
  • Management:
    • Antiretroviral therapy (ART) is the cornerstone, as immune reconstitution leads to regression.
    • Chemotherapy (liposomal doxorubicin, paclitaxel) for extensive disease.
    • Radiotherapy or cryotherapy for localized lesions.

Explanation of other options:

Basal cell carcinoma (Option A): Typically presents as pearly nodules on sun-exposed skin, not as violaceous mucosal lesions.

Malignant melanoma (Option C): Presents as dark, irregular pigmented lesions, not characteristic violaceous plaques.

Squamous cell carcinoma (Option D): Can occur in the oral cavity but appears as ulcerated, keratotic growths, not violaceous patches.

Reference:

PubMed - 23679875

questions.text: A patient is brought to the OPD by his wife complaining about difficulty in expressing emotions and not taking part in daily activities. On examination, resting tremors and rigidity are noted. Given the possible diagnosis, which part of the brain is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Basal ganglia degeneration, particularly in the substantia nigra, leads to the classic motor symptoms of Parkinson's disease including resting tremors and rigidity.

  • The patient's symptoms-difficulty expressing emotions, reduced participation in daily activities, along with resting tremors and rigidity-are classic features of Parkinson's disease, a neurodegenerative disorder primarily involving the basal ganglia.
  • More specifically, the substantia nigra pars compacta, a component of the basal ganglia, undergoes dopaminergic neuron degeneration, leading to dopamine deficiency in the striatal pathways.
  • This disrupts the balance of the direct and indirect motor pathways, resulting in motor symptoms like bradykinesia, resting tremors, rigidity, and later, postural instability.
  • Additionally, non-motor features such as emotional blunting and apathy are linked to dysfunction in the limbic circuits of the basal ganglia.
  • Key features of Parkinson's disease:
    • Rigidity: Resistance to passive limb movement ("lead-pipe" or "cogwheel").
    • Resting tremor: Classically described as "pill-rolling" tremor.
    • Bradykinesia: General slowness of voluntary movement.
    • Postural instability: Late features causing impaired balance and frequent falls.

Explanation of other options:

Hippocampus (Option B): Involved mainly in memory consolidation and spatial learning; not associated with motor features like tremor or rigidity.

Cerebellum (Option C): Lesions cause intention tremor, ataxia, and dysmetria-;not the resting tremor or rigidity seen in Parkinson's disease.

Premotor cortex (Option D): Responsible for motor planning and initiation. Lesions here may cause apraxia but are not the primary site of pathology in Parkinson's disease.

Brain Lesions Locations and their Consequences:

Reference:

https://journals.plos.org/ploscompbiol/article?id=10.1371/journal.pcbi.1000408

https://academic.oup.com/brain/article/138/10/3061/2468715

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV-positive male came with complaints of persistent cough and weight loss. He has skin lesions that appear as umbilicated papules and nodules predominantly on the face, trunk, and upper extremities. Chest x-ray showed multiple bilateral nodular infiltrates. His sputum CBNAAT for tuberculosis was negative and he has a low CD4 count. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Disseminated histoplasmosis commonly presents with systemic symptoms, pulmonary infiltrates, and skin lesions in immunocompromised individuals, particularly those with HIV and low CD4 counts.

  • Histoplasma capsulatum, a dimorphic fungus, causes disseminated histoplasmosis in immunocompromised patients, especially those with CD4+ counts <200/μL.
  • Infection is acquired via inhalation of microconidia from bird or bat droppings.
  • In such patients, the yeast forms multiply within macrophages and spread systemically.
  • Clinical features of progressive disseminated histoplasmosis (PDH) include fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly, pancytopenia, diffuse interstitial or reticulonodular pulmonary infiltrates, and characteristic skin lesions (papules, plaques, ulcers, sometimes umbilicated in ~10% cases).
  • Diagnosis involves urine or serum antigen testing, fungal cultures, and histopathological identification of yeast within macrophages.
  • Treatment: Liposomal amphotericin B is used for induction in severe cases, followed by oral itraconazole maintenance for ≥12 months.

Explanation of other options:

HIV with disseminated cryptococcosis (Option B): Cryptococcosis usually presents with meningeal involvement; the absence of neurological signs and predominant lung and skin involvement makes this less likely.

HIV with molluscum contagiosum (Option C): While the patient has umbilicated papules, molluscum contagiosum does not explain systemic symptoms or lung infiltrates.

HIV with tuberculosis (Option D): Although TB is common in HIV, a negative sputum CBNAAT and bilateral nodular infiltrates without typical granulomatous findings reduce its likelihood.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3687172/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3969680/

questions.text: A male patient presented to the emergency room with seizures. He has a history of fever, headache, and confusion. An MRI brain was done, and it showed inflammation involving the bitemporal lobes. What is the most likely aetiology for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

HSV encephalitis classically involves the bitemporal lobes and presents with fever, seizures, confusion, and behavioural changes.

Explanation of other options:

Cytomegalovirus (Option A): Typically seen in immunocompromised individuals; MRI shows periventricular calcifications and ventricular enlargement, not bitemporal lobe involvement.

Toxoplasma gondii (Option B): Common in immunocompromised hosts; presents with multiple ring-enhancing lesions in the basal ganglia or corticomedullary junction, not the temporal lobes.

Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Option D): TB meningitis or encephalitis presents with diffuse cortical involvement and basal exudates; bitemporal localisation is not characteristic.

Reference:

Radiopaedia: Tuberculous Encephalopathy

choices.text: Subacute combined degeneration of the cord

questions.text: A male patient presents with sensory loss and limb weakness for 3 months. He also has angular stomatitis. On examination, there is loss of proprioception and vibration sensation, UMN-type weakness in the lower limbs, and absent ankle reflexes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vitamin B12 deficiency causes subacute combined degeneration with posterior column and corticospinal tract involvement, explaining the mixed sensory and UMN findings.

Subacute Combined Degeneration of the Cord (SACD)

  • Neurological disorder due to vitamin B12 deficiency, causing demyelination of the posterior columns and lateral corticospinal tracts.
  • Etiology
    • Vitamin B12 Deficiency:
      • Pernicious anemia.
      • Gastrectomy or ileal resection.
      • Diphyllobothrium latum infestation.
      • Long-term use of metformin or PPIs.
  • Affected Areas
    • Posterior columns: Loss of proprioception and vibration sense.
    • Lateral corticospinal tracts: Spasticity and UMN-type weakness.
  • Clinical Features
    • Sensory Symptoms:
      • Loss of proprioception and vibration sense: Begins in lower limbs, may progress to upper limbs.
      • Sensory ataxia: Positive Romberg's test (difficulty standing with eyes closed).
      • Paresthesia: Tingling or numbness in extremities, typically in a glove-and-stocking distribution.
    • Motor Symptoms:
      • Upper motor neuron signs: Weakness, spasticity, and hyperreflexia.
      • Spastic weakness: Due to lateral corticospinal tract involvement.
      • Absent ankle reflex: A key finding, coexisting with UMN signs due to concurrent peripheral neuropathy
  • Signs:
    • Lhermitte's Sign: Electric shock-like sensation down the spine on neck flexion.
    • Angular stomatitis
    • Optic neuropathy
  • Non-neurological Features:
    • Megaloblastic anemia: fatigue, pallor, glossitis, and jaundice.
  • Psychiatric Symptoms:
    • Irritability, dementia, psychosis.
    • Depression and memory loss.
  • Treatment
    • Vitamin B12 Replacement:
      • IM cyanocobalamin or hydroxocobalamin.
      • Oral B12 for maintenance.
  • Address underlying causes (e.g., anemia, parasitic infestation).

Explanation of other options:

Extradural cord compression (Option A): Presents with localized back pain, radicular symptoms, asymmetric deficits, and early bladder/bowel dysfunction. It doesn't explain angular stomatitis or symmetrical sensory loss.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (Option B): ALS involves UMN and LMN signs without sensory involvement. Sensory deficits and angular stomatitis rule this out.

Multiple sclerosis (Option C): MS presents with optic neuritis, sensory changes, and gait issues, often with remissions. However, angular stomatitis and absent ankle reflex with UMN signs are not typical features.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with complaints of chest pain, palpitations, and shortness of breath. On examination, a mid-diastolic murmur is heard, and a prominent 'a'wave is noted in the jugular venous pulse (JVP). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A mid-diastolic murmur with a prominent 'a' wave in JVP points towards tricuspid stenosis, due to impaired right atrial emptying and elevated right atrial pressure.

  • Tricuspid stenosis (TS) is characterized by narrowing of the tricuspid valve, leading to obstruction of blood flow from the right atrium to the right ventricle during diastole.
  • This results in elevated right atrial pressure, producing a prominent 'a' wave in JVP, due to forceful atrial contraction against a stenotic valve.
  • The mid-diastolic murmur is typically heard best at the lower left sternal border or over the xiphoid and is accentuated during inspiration (Carvallo's sign), due to increased venous return to the right heart.
  • Other features include right atrial enlargement, evident as tall, peaked P waves in inferior leads (II, III, aVF) on ECG.
  • Hepatomegaly, ascites, and peripheral edema may also be present in advanced cases.

Types of Murmurs:

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of hypertension on multiple antihypertensive medications came to the OPD. His ECG finding is given below. Which of the following drugs is responsible for the ECG finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Spironolactone can cause hyperkalemia, which presents on ECG as tall, peaked T waves.

  • The ECG finding of tall, peaked T waves is a classic sign of hyperkalemia.
  • Among the given options, spironolactone is the most likely culprit because it is a potassium-sparing diuretic.
  • It acts by blocking aldosterone receptors in the distal tubule and collecting duct, thereby inhibiting sodium reabsorption and reducing potassium excretion.
  • This leads to potassium retention, raising serum potassium levels and causing hyperkalemia.
  • ECG changes in hyperkalemia progress with severity:

Explanation of other options:

Prazosin (Option A): Alpha-1 blocker used in hypertension; not associated with hyperkalemia.

Metoprolol (Option B): Beta-blocker; does not usually cause hyperkalemia, though rare cases exist in renal dysfunction.

Hydrochlorothiazide (Option C): Thiazide diuretic that promotes potassium loss, leading to hypokalemia rather than hyperkalemia.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6205312/

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman presents with a progressive decline in daily activity. She gives a history of convulsions and visual hallucinations. She does not talk to anyone and keeps looking at the sky. Pathological examination shows the presence of Lewy bodies within the neurons. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Lewy bodies in neurons along with progressive motor and cognitive decline are hallmark features of Parkinson's disease.

  • Parkinson's disease is a neurodegenerative disorder marked by the loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra.
  • A key pathological feature is the presence of Lewy bodies-eosinophilic, intracytoplasmic inclusions primarily composed of alpha-synuclein.
  • Patients typically present with motor symptoms like bradykinesia, rigidity, resting tremor, and postural instability.
  • In later stages, non-motor symptoms such as cognitive decline, visual hallucinations, sleep disturbances, and behavioral changes can occur-consistent with this patient's clinical presentation.
  • Convulsions are rare but can be seen in late-stage disease or in Parkinson's disease dementia.
  • Management involves dopaminergic therapies like levodopa/carbidopa, dopamine agonists, and MAO-B inhibitors.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5771416/

https://www.nia.nih.gov/health/alzheimers-and-dementia/understanding-different-types-dementia

choices.text: DDAVP for 2 weeks and then discontinue
Upsetting of receptors, so no treatment required

questions.text: A patient came to medical OPD with complaints of polyuria. He has a history of undergoing total hypophysectomy. His Na+ levels were found to be 155 mEq/L, and his urine osmolarity was 200 mOsm/L. What is the definitive management in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lifelong desmopressin (DDAVP) is the definitive treatment for central diabetes insipidus following total hypophysectomy.

  • This patient has central diabetes insipidus (DI), a condition resulting from decreased vasopressin (ADH) secretion due to complete removal of the pituitary gland.
  • Clinical features include polyuria, hypernatremia (Na = 155 mEq/L), and low urine osmolality (200 mOsm/kg), all indicating impaired water reabsorption.
  • The definitive treatment is lifelong DDAVP (desmopressin), a synthetic ADH analog that restores water retention and corrects electrolyte imbalance.

Explanation of other options:

DDAVP for 2 weeks and then discontinue (Option A): Inappropriate, as hypophysectomy causes permanent ADH deficiency.

Upsetting of receptors, so no treatment required (Option C): Incorrect; central DI involves hormone deficiency, not receptor issues.

Thiazides for 2 weeks (Option D): Used in nephrogenic DI, not effective in central DI where ADH is lacking.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470458/

questions.text: A 65-year-old chronic smoker came to the medicine outpatient department with complaints of upper chest discomfort and drooping of an eyelid. He also complained of pain radiating to the upper arm and a tingling sensation in the 4th and 5th digits of his right hand. The chest X-ray is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The classic triad of shoulder pain, Horner's syndrome, and arm symptoms suggests a Pancoast tumor involving the apex of the lung.

  • A Pancoast tumor (superior sulcus tumor) is a non-small cell lung carcinoma (usually squamous or adenocarcinoma) that arises at the lung apex, commonly in smokers.
  • It invades surrounding structures such as the brachial plexus and sympathetic chain, leading to:
    • Shoulder/arm pain (C8-T2 involvement)
    • Horners syndrome (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis)
      • Ptosis (drooping eyelid)
      • Miosis (pupil constriction)
      • Anhidrosis (loss of sweating on the affected side)
    • Hand weakness and tingling in the ulnar distribution (C8-T1 nerve roots)
  • Diagnosis:
    • Chest X-ray: Apical mass
    • MRI (Investigation of Choice): Defines local invasion
    • Biopsy: For histological confirmation
    • PET scan: For metastasis workup
  • Management:
    • Radiotherapy (pre-op), surgery (e.g., lobectomy), and chemotherapy depending on resectability.

Explanation of other options:

Superior vena cava obstruction (Option B): Causes facial/upper limb swelling, not ptosis or brachial plexus symptoms; more associated with anterior mediastinal masses.

Upper lobe pneumonia (Option C): May cause chest pain and consolidation on imaging but lacks neuro signs like ptosis or arm tingling.

Aspergilloma (Option D): Occurs in pre-existing lung cavities (post-TB), presents with hemoptysis or cough, not Horner's syndrome or brachial plexopathy.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presents with acute pain and swelling of the left great toe. There is no history of trauma. Synovial fluid analysis shows raised leukocytes. Lab investigations show normal serum uric acid levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Acute gout is the most likely diagnosis due to the classic presentation of podagra, even with normal serum uric acid levels during an acute flare.

  • This patient presents with acute monoarthritis of the first metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint (known as podagra), which is highly characteristic of acute gout-a condition caused by the deposition of monosodium urate (MSU) crystals in joints.
  • Although serum uric acid is often elevated in gout, normal uric acid levels do not rule out gout during an acute attack.

Gout

  • Gout is an inflammatory arthritis caused by MSU crystal deposition in joints and soft tissues due to hyperuricemia.
  • However, the uric acid levels may be normal during flares due to crystal precipitation into the joint.
  • Etiology of Gout:
    • Primary Gout:
      • Genetic defects in purine metabolism
      • Decreased renal excretion of uric acid
    • Secondary Gout:
      • Chronic kidney disease, malignancy, or increased cell turnover (e.g., tumor lysis)
      • Medications: Diuretics, low-dose aspirin
      • Diet: Alcohol, red meat, seafood-especially relevant here as the patient is a chronic alcoholic
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Hyperuricemia leads to precipitation of MSU crystals in joints.
    • These crystals trigger activation of NLRP3 inflammasome in macrophages → release of IL-1β, causing intense inflammation.
  • Clinical Features of Gout:
    • Asymptomatic hyperuricemia may be present without symptoms.
    • Acute Gout Attack: Sudden onset of joint pain, swelling, erythema, and warmth; especially at night.
      • Most commonly affects the first MTP joint (podagra).
    • Intercritical gout: Symptom-free intervals between flares
    • Chronic tophaceous gout: Formation of tophi, chalky urate deposits in joints and soft tissues.
  • Diagnosis of Gout:
    • Synovial Fluid Analysis:
      • Gold standard for diagnosis
      • Presence of needle-shaped, negatively birefringent MSU crystals under polarized light microscopy
    • Serum Uric Acid:
      • Often >6.8 mg/dL, but may be normal during an acute attack.
  • Imaging Findings:
    • X-ray: Punched-out erosions in chronic gout
    • Ultrasound: Double-contour sign
    • Dual-energy CT: Detects urate deposits
    • Martel sign: Erosions with sclerotic margins and overhanging edges
  • Management of Gout:
    • Acute Attack:
      • Colchicine: 0.6 mg TID (adjust in renal impairment)
      • NSAIDs: Indomethacin, naproxen (avoid in CKD)
      • Glucocorticoids: Used if NSAIDs/colchicine contraindicated
      • Canakinumab: IL-1β inhibitor in resistant cases
      • Ice therapy: Adjunctive anti-inflammatory
    • Post-Attack Management:
      • Goal: Serum uric acid < 5-6 mg/dL
      • Allopurinol: First-line xanthine oxidase inhibitor
      • Febuxostat: Alternative when allopurinol is contraindicated
      • Probenecid/Sulfinpyrazone: Uricosuric agents (avoid in renal dysfunction)
      • Pegloticase: Refractory cases
      • Lifestyle: Avoid alcohol, red meat, seafood

Explanation of other options:

Pseudogout (Option A): Caused by calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPPD) crystal deposition, typically affects knee, wrist, elbow, and shoulder rather than the big toe. Crystals are rhomboid-shaped and positively birefringent under polarized light.

Reactive Arthritis (Option C): A post-infectious arthritis typically following GI or GU infections, and classically presents with the triad: arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis. It does not fit this monoarticular toe presentation.

Septic Arthritis (Option D): Usually involves larger joints like knee or hip, not typically the toe. Synovial fluid would show very high WBCs, purulent fluid, and may grow bacteria on culture. Fever is commonly present, which is absent here.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK546606/

Anakinra - LiverTox - NCBI Bookshelf

Colchicine - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: Please determine the medical condition related to the image provided.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Marfan syndrome commonly causes mitral valve prolapse and mitral regurgitation due to connective tissue abnormalities.

  • The image and clinical features suggest Marfan Syndrome, a connective tissue disorder inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern due to FBN1 gene mutation on chromosome 15, leading to abnormal fibrillin-1 protein.
  • This weakens connective tissue, particularly affecting the cardiovascular, ocular, and musculoskeletal systems.
  • Cardiac manifestations include aortic root dilation, aortic dissection, mitral valve prolapse, and mitral regurgitation-the latter being the most common cardiac complication.
  • Mitral regurgitation occurs due to valve floppiness and improper closure, causing backflow of blood into the left atrium during systole.
  • Key features of Marfan Syndrome:
    • Facial/Ocular: Long face, high-arched palate, ectopia lentis (superotemporal), myopia.
    • Musculoskeletal: Tall stature, arachnodactyly, pectus excavatum/carinatum, scoliosis, positive thumb (Steinberg) and wrist (Walker-Murdoch) signs.
    • Cardiovascular: Aortic root dilation, dissection (most common cause of death), mitral regurgitation.
    • Diagnosis: Based on Ghent criteria, supported by genetic testing and echocardiography.
      • Major criteria:
        • Aortic root dilation.
        • Ectopia lentis.
        • Skeletal features (e.g., arachnodactyly, scoliosis).
        • Family history of Marfan syndrome.
      • Minor criteria:
        • Joint hypermobility, myopia, high palate.
        • Genetic testing for FBN1 mutation confirms diagnosis
    • Management: Beta-blockers/ARBs, regular imaging, surgical repair of aortic root or mitral valve if needed.

Explanation of other options:

Aortic Stenosis (Option B): Typically due to calcific degeneration or congenital bicuspid valve; not a classic feature of Marfan syndrome.

Aortic Regurgitation (Option C): Can occur in Marfan's due to aortic dilation, but mitral regurgitation is more common and primary in early stages.

Mitral Stenosis (Option D): Usually post-rheumatic in origin and unrelated to connective tissue disorders like Marfan's.
